oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:title: Major Ridge
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:description: Portrait of Cherokee leader Major Ridge wearing a blue coat, brown vest, and white shirt.

Major Ridge (approximately 1771-1839) was a warrior of the Cherokees born at Hiwassee, now Polk County, Tennessee. He distinguished himself in the Creek War (1813-1814), organizing Cherokee volunteers to fight with Andrew Jackson against the Creeks. He rose in prominence among the Cherokee nation, becoming Speaker of the Council in 1827. Ridge's power eventually waned after he sided with the Cherokee faction advocating removal west of the Mississippi, resulting in the infamous Trail of Tears. His participation in the Treaty of New Echota led to his execution in 1839.
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:creator: McKenney, Thomas L. (Thomas Loraine), 1785-1859; Hall, James, 1793-1868
